elements.title: The Weekly Glance: From Vigilance to Ease Over 13 Weeks
elements.problem: The Stays Manager is the most-visited page in the guest journey -- 13+ visits over a single lease. On Week 1, the guest arrives uncertain: they do not yet know whether the platform is reliable, whether their stay information is accurate, or whether anything will go wrong. Their System 2 is fully engaged in parsing a new interface. By Week 7, the guest has developed expectations but also accumulated fatigue from weekly administrative prompts (reviews, photo uploads). By Week 13, the guest is either comfortably habituated or resentfully checked-out. The emotional arc of the Stays Manager determines whether the guest renews, recommends, or abandons. Currently, the flat table design delivers the same emotional experience on Week 1 and Week 13: a wall of data rows that demands System 2 scanning. There is no emotional progression. The page does not reward the guest for returning, does not acknowledge their growing familiarity, and does not adapt its tone to the stage of the relationship. Kahneman's skill acquisition research shows that repeated tasks should feel easier with practice -- but a table that grows each week makes the experience harder, not easier, creating an emotional trajectory of increasing frustration rather than increasing comfort.
elements.solution: Design the Stays Manager's emotional arc across three distinct phases. Week 1-3 (Orientation): the tone is warm, gently instructional, and reassuring. The hero card includes a brief orientation note ('This card updates each week with your current stay'). Copy uses complete sentences. The feeling is 'we are guiding you.' Week 4-9 (Routine): the tone shifts to efficient and confident. Orientation hints disappear. Copy becomes terse and data-forward. The feeling is 'you know how this works; here is what you need.' Week 10-13 (Appreciation): the tone shifts to reflective and grateful. The hero card acknowledges the approaching end ('3 weeks remaining'). The final review prompt is framed warmly. The feeling is 'thank you for being here.' The emotional arc maps to Kahneman's cognitive ease gradient: Week 1 requires System 2 (unfamiliar interface), so the emotional design compensates with warmth. By Week 7, System 1 handles the page (familiar pattern), so the emotional design steps back to efficiency. By Week 13, the relationship deserves acknowledgment, so the design re-engages with human warmth.

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week... 2-3 month commitments typical.
evidence.insight: The hybrid worker visits weekly for months. Each visit is a micro-interaction competing with work. The emotional design must respect this rhythm: warm when the guest is new and uncertain, invisible when the guest is habituated, and appreciative when the guest has invested months of loyalty.

evidence.quote: As you become skilled in a task, its demand for energy diminishes... A general 'law of least effort' applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion.
evidence.insight: As the guest becomes skilled at reading the Stays Manager, the emotional design must shift from compensating for cognitive effort (warm guidance) to matching cognitive ease (clean efficiency). A design that stays warm and instructional on Week 10 feels patronizing. A design that is terse on Week 1 feels cold.

elements.emotion_rationale: Belonging is the emotional endpoint of a 13-week relationship. Week 1 is about trust. Week 7 is about comfort. Week 13 is about belonging -- the guest should feel that this platform knows them, respects their time, and values their presence. Belonging is what converts a transactional lease into a relationship that drives renewal and referral.

copy_guidelines.voice: warm evolving to efficient to grateful
do: Week 1-3: use complete sentences with context ('Your first stay is this week. Here is what to expect.')
Week 4-9: use terse, data-forward phrases ('Week 7: Oct 14-18. In Progress.')
Week 10-13: add human acknowledgment ('3 weeks remaining. Thank you for being a great guest.')
Use the guest's name at least once on the page across all phases
Reference specific data (dates, property name) rather than generic placeholders
dont: Maintain the same tone from Week 1 through Week 13 -- the relationship evolves and the voice must evolve with it
Use instructional language after Week 3 -- it signals the platform does not trust the guest to know how it works
Use corporate farewell language at lease end ('We hope you enjoyed your experience!') -- it sounds automated
Over-celebrate routine actions ('Amazing! You checked your stay!') -- it feels condescending to a busy professional
copy_guidelines.example_good: Week 7: 'Week 7 of 13. Oct 14-18. All set.' -- Efficient, respectful of the guest's time, acknowledges progress without fanfare.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Week 7: 'Welcome back to your Stays Manager! Here is your weekly update for your stay at the property.' -- Overly formal, wastes words, treats the guest like a first-time visitor.

animation_feel.feel_description: A settling exhale. The hero card loads with a fast start and gentle deceleration, like sitting down in a familiar chair. On Week 1, the card entrance is slightly slower (300ms) to give the guest time to register the new element. By Week 4+, the entrance is faster (200ms) because the guest knows where to look. The sensation across all weeks is arrival without effort -- the information meets the guest where they are, rather than making them search for it.
animation_feel.duration_range: 200-300ms, decreasing over the lease as familiarity grows

tension_relief.tension_point: Does the platform still have my correct stay information? Has anything changed since last week?
tension_relief.relief_point: The hero card loads instantly with the current week's data, confirming everything is accurate and on track. No scanning needed.
tension_relief.timing: Relief must arrive within 2 seconds of page load. The hero card answers both questions (correct data, nothing changed) in a single glance.

personalization_signals: Hero card shows the guest's current week number out of total ('Week 7 of 13'), acknowledging their journey progress
After a completed date change, the hero card briefly notes the change ('Updated: Oct 15 swapped for Oct 22') so the guest sees the platform registered their action
On the first visit after a batched review milestone, the hero card thanks the guest by name if a review was submitted
The lease duration context adapts: early weeks show 'Getting started', mid-lease shows nothing extra, late weeks show 'X weeks remaining'

anti_patterns.pattern: Same emotional tone on every visit regardless of lease week
anti_patterns.reason: A static tone fails to mirror the guest's evolving relationship with the platform. Week 1 uncertainty and Week 13 familiarity are different emotional states that require different tonal responses. Treating them identically signals the platform is not paying attention.
anti_patterns.example_bad: 'Welcome to your Stays Manager' displayed identically on Week 1 and Week 13.

elements.title: The Price Surprise Shield: Preventing Betrayal Before It Forms
elements.problem: Nneka states that rescheduling at the original rate is 'not working financially' because seasonal pricing has increased from $1,170-$1,175 to a higher rate. Brad anchored on the original price -- it was the first financial number he evaluated, and Kahneman's anchoring research shows that first numbers become the reference point against which all subsequent numbers are judged. When Brad encounters a higher rate during rescheduling, the emotional experience is not 'the market price changed' but 'I was promised one price and now they want more.' This is the betrayal emotion -- the most destructive feeling in a platform relationship. Betrayal is not caused by the price increase itself; it is caused by the gap between what the guest expected and what they encountered. The platform currently makes no effort to close this gap before it opens. The listing page shows one nightly rate. The proposal confirms one total. The rescheduling section uses abstract labels ('fair market rate calculation') instead of concrete numbers. At every stage, the emotional setup is 'your price is fixed' and the emotional payoff is 'your price changed.' This sequence manufactures betrayal.
elements.solution: Prevent the betrayal emotion by eliminating the expectation gap before commitment. At listing evaluation, when dates span pricing seasons, show the rate range ('$280-$301/night depending on season') so the guest's anchor is a range, not a single number. At proposal confirmation, include a one-line seasonal note ('Date changes are priced at the rate for the new dates'). At every date change in the Stays Manager, show the original rate next to the new rate with the delta. The emotional principle is: prepare the guest for variability before they experience it. A guest who was told 'rates vary by season' and then sees a seasonal adjustment feels informed. A guest who was shown one rate and then sees a different rate feels deceived. The emotional architecture is identical to Kahneman's Muller-Lyer illusion: you cannot change the feeling (the higher rate will always feel worse than the original), but you can prevent the surprise that amplifies the feeling into betrayal.

evidence.quote: It's not working financially... Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175. And that was... therefore I am not able to do that.
evidence.insight: The host cannot honor the original rate for rescheduled dates. The guest (Brad) will experience the rate increase as a betrayal of the original agreement because his System 1 anchored on the first number. The emotional damage is not proportional to the dollar amount -- it is proportional to the gap between expectation and reality.

evidence.quote: Now that you have measured the lines, you -- your System 2 -- have a new belief: you know that the lines are equally long. But you still see the bottom line as longer.
evidence.insight: The Muller-Lyer illusion proves that knowing something is fair does not make it feel fair. Even after the guest understands seasonal pricing, their System 1 will still feel the original rate is the 'real' rate. The design cannot eliminate this illusion but can prevent the surprise that transforms a mild discomfort into active distrust.

elements.emotion_rationale: Fairness is the antidote to betrayal. When a guest encounters a price change and feels it was fairly disclosed and transparently calculated, the emotional response shifts from 'they tricked me' to 'the market moved and I was prepared.' Fairness does not require the guest to like the price -- it requires them to feel the process was honest. Fairness at the moment of price disclosure determines whether the guest stays or churns.

do: Show both the original rate and the new rate side by side -- comparison is the foundation of perceived fairness
Use neutral market language: 'rate for the requested date' instead of 'price increase' or 'surcharge'
Explain the why briefly: 'Jan-Feb rates are higher due to seasonal demand' -- one sentence of context
Show the delta explicitly, even when it is $0, to build trust in the system's transparency
dont: Apologize for the price difference ('Sorry, rates have changed') -- apologies imply wrongdoing and amplify the betrayal feeling
Hide the comparison by showing only the new rate -- the absence of context creates suspicion
Frame the price change as the guest's fault ('Because you are rescheduling...') -- the guest should not feel punished for flexibility
Use persuasive language to justify the price ('This is actually a great rate!') -- let the numbers speak for themselves
copy_guidelines.example_good: Your original rate: $280/night. Rate for Oct 22: $301/night. Difference: +$21. (Jan-Feb seasonal rate.)
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Unfortunately, due to seasonal pricing adjustments, your new rate will be $301/night. We apologize for any inconvenience.

animation_feel.feel_description: A calm reveal. When the rate comparison appears, both numbers (original and new) arrive simultaneously with a gentle fade-in, not sequentially. Sequential reveal (old rate... then new rate) creates dramatic tension that amplifies the price shock. Simultaneous reveal presents the comparison as a static fact rather than an unfolding surprise. The sensation is reading a receipt, not watching a price ticker.
animation_feel.duration_range: 150-200ms for the comparison to fully appear

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest discovers the rescheduled date costs more than their original rate. Their System 1 flags this as a potential deception.
tension_relief.relief_point: The comparison display shows both rates side by side with the delta and a one-line seasonal explanation. The guest sees the system is transparent, not manipulative.
tension_relief.timing: The relief must be simultaneous with the tension. The guest should never see the new rate without immediately seeing the original rate and the delta. If there is even a 500ms gap between 'new rate appears' and 'comparison context appears,' the betrayal emotion activates.

personalization_signals: Show the guest's specific original rate, not a generic 'original rates start at...'
Reference the guest's specific dates: 'Your Oct 15 rate was $280. Oct 22 rate is $301.'
If the guest has made previous date changes at $0 delta, reference that: 'Your last swap was cost-neutral. This one has a seasonal adjustment.'
Cumulative disclosure: 'You have paid $X in seasonal adjustments across your lease' -- makes the total visible rather than hidden across individual changes

anti_patterns.pattern: Showing only the new price without a comparison to the original
anti_patterns.reason: Without comparison, the guest must recall the original rate from memory and compute the delta themselves. Under ego depletion, they will get it wrong or not bother -- and the uncertainty will feel like deception even if the difference is small.

elements.title: The Waiting Ache: Resolving Proposal Anxiety Through Status Visibility
elements.problem: After submitting a proposal, the guest enters an emotionally vulnerable state: they have committed to wanting a place to stay, but they do not know if they will get it. Kahneman describes how System 2 is activated when 'an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.' The guest's model after submission is 'I acted, something should happen.' When the platform shows no change -- no acknowledgment, no timeline, no indication that the host has seen the proposal -- System 2 stays activated in monitoring mode. This is not a one-time activation; it is a persistent, low-grade cognitive drain that competes with the guest's work responsibilities. Brad's behavior confirms this pattern: he texts Nneka directly because the platform provides no channel for resolving the uncertainty. The emotional cost of this opacity is not just anxiety -- it is helplessness. The guest cannot do anything to accelerate the process, cannot see whether progress is happening, and cannot plan their housing situation. Helplessness is the most disempowering emotion a platform can inflict, and it is entirely created by the absence of status information.
elements.solution: Replace helplessness with informed patience. At every stage of the proposal pipeline, provide three pieces of emotional infrastructure: (1) Acknowledgment: 'Your proposal was received and sent to [host name].' This validates the guest's action. (2) Timeline: 'Hosts typically respond within 48 hours. Submitted 14 hours ago.' This converts open-ended uncertainty into bounded waiting. (3) Agency: 'If you do not hear back by [date], you can send a reminder or contact support.' This gives the guest a future action to hold onto, preventing the feeling that they are entirely at the mercy of the host. The emotional principle is: the guest can tolerate waiting if they know what they are waiting for, how long it should take, and what they can do if it takes too long. Open-ended, information-free waiting is emotionally intolerable. Bounded, transparent waiting is manageable.

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day... if I have availability.
evidence.insight: Brad texts because the platform provides no status channel. The emotional driver is not impatience -- it is the inability to tolerate uncertainty without any information. A status display that says 'waiting on host, expected response within 48 hours' would reduce the emotional urgency of the text.

evidence.quote: System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.
evidence.insight: The guest's mental model after submission is 'something should happen next.' When nothing visibly happens, System 2 activates to monitor the gap. This activation is emotionally experienced as anxiety -- the cognitive strain of unresolved uncertainty. Status updates resolve the gap by confirming that the process is proceeding even when the guest cannot see it.

elements.emotion_rationale: Assurance is the opposite of helplessness. The guest who feels assured knows that the process is working, knows when to expect a result, and knows what they can do if the result does not arrive. Assurance does not require certainty of outcome -- it requires certainty of process. A guest can be assured that 'hosts typically respond within 48 hours' even though they do not know what the response will be.

do: Name the person the guest is waiting on: 'Waiting on [host name]' not 'Waiting on host response'
Provide specific time context: 'Submitted 14 hours ago' and 'Hosts typically respond within 48 hours'
Offer a future action: 'No response by Friday? You can send a reminder.'
Acknowledge the guest's emotional state implicitly: 'We will notify you the moment [host name] responds' -- the promise of notification is itself reassuring
dont: Use vague status language: 'Processing' without a timeline is anxiety, not information
Over-reassure: 'Do not worry! Your host will get back to you soon!' -- this patronizes the guest and provides no useful information
Hide the elapsed time: showing 'Submitted 14 hours ago' is more comforting than hiding the clock, because it proves the system is tracking
Make the guest feel they must monitor: 'Check back soon for updates' creates an obligation to poll, which is the opposite of assurance
copy_guidelines.example_good: Waiting on Nneka. Submitted 14h ago. Hosts typically respond within 48h. We will notify you when she responds.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Your proposal is being reviewed. Please check back later for updates.

animation_feel.feel_description: A patient pulse. During waiting states, the current pipeline stage uses a very slow, barely perceptible breathing animation on the action assignment tag (opacity oscillates between 0.8 and 1.0 over 3 seconds). This communicates 'the system is alive and watching' without creating urgency. The sensation is like seeing the steady blink of a charging indicator -- it confirms activity without demanding attention. When the status changes (host responds), the breathing stops and the stage transition animation plays, creating a crisp contrast between waiting and progress.
animation_feel.duration_range: 3000ms breathing cycle during waiting states; 300-400ms for stage transition animations

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest submitted a proposal or date change request and does not know if it was seen, is being reviewed, or was forgotten.
tension_relief.relief_point: The pipeline shows exactly who must act, how long ago the request was sent, and what the expected response time is. A push notification confirms the moment the host responds.
tension_relief.timing: Partial relief is immediate (status display on submission). Full relief arrives when the host responds (push notification + pipeline update). The design must provide enough partial relief that the guest does not feel compelled to text the host or check the platform repeatedly.

personalization_signals: Use the host's actual name in status messages: 'Waiting on Nneka' not 'Waiting on host'
Show the host's typical response time if data is available: 'Nneka usually responds within 12 hours'
After the first proposal, subsequent proposals skip instructional text and show just the status
If the guest has previously experienced a fast host response, set expectations accordingly: 'Nneka responded to your last request in 6 hours'

anti_patterns.pattern: A waiting state with no timeline, no action assignment, and no future agency
anti_patterns.reason: Open-ended, information-free waiting triggers helplessness -- the most disempowering emotion in a platform experience. The guest cannot plan, cannot act, and cannot even estimate when they will be able to plan or act. This is the emotional state that drives off-platform workarounds (texting the host) and eventually platform abandonment.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Your proposal is under review. We will let you know when there is an update.

elements.title: The Text Message Temptation: Making the Platform Feel Easier Than Informal Channels
elements.problem: Brad texts Nneka to reschedule because texting is the path of least emotional resistance. A text message feels personal, immediate, and low-commitment: 'Hey, can I switch Thursday for Tuesday?' takes 10 seconds and creates no formal record. The platform, by contrast, feels official, slow, and consequential: filling out a form, clicking submit, waiting for a system response. Kahneman's law of least effort predicts that the guest will always choose the cognitively easier path. But the emotional dimension is equally important: texting feels human and casual; the platform feels institutional and formal. The guest is not just choosing the easier path -- they are choosing the path that feels less like doing paperwork and more like talking to a person. This emotional preference for informality over formality is particularly strong for the target persona (hybrid workers managing demanding jobs) who spend their workdays in formal systems and crave informality in their personal logistics. The platform currently offers no emotional counterweight to this preference: it looks and feels like a management console, not a conversation.
elements.solution: Design every guest-initiated interaction during active_lease to feel conversational rather than administrative. The date change flow should feel like sending a message, not filing a request. The copy should mirror the casual language of a text message: 'Swap Thu for Tue?' rather than 'Submit Date Change Request.' The response from the system should feel like a reply: 'Got it. Sent to Nneka. She usually responds within a day.' The emotional principle is: the platform must feel like a smarter version of the text thread, not a replacement for it. The guest should think 'I could text Nneka, but the platform is just as easy and keeps track of everything.' This means: (1) Input speed must match texting speed -- three taps, not three form fields. (2) Language must match texting casualness -- first names, short sentences, no jargon. (3) Feedback must match texting immediacy -- instant acknowledgment, not 'your request has been submitted.' (4) The emotional reward of using the platform must exceed texting: the guest sees available dates (no guessing), sees the cost impact (no surprises), and has a record (no 'did I already text her about Tuesday?').

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day... if I have availability.
evidence.insight: The emotional texture of Brad's rescheduling is casual human conversation: 'Hey, I can't make it, can I do another day?' The platform must match this emotional texture while adding the structural benefits (availability checking, pricing calculation, record keeping) that texting lacks.

evidence.quote: A general 'law of least effort' applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion. The law asserts that if there are several ways of achieving the same goal, people will eventually gravitate to the least demanding course of action.
evidence.insight: The least demanding path is emotional as well as cognitive. Texting feels easy because it is informal. A platform form feels hard because it is formal. The platform must reduce both cognitive load (fewer taps) and emotional load (casual tone) to compete with texting.

elements.emotion_rationale: Ease is the feeling that the platform is not work. The hybrid worker already spends 8+ hours per day in formal, cognitively demanding systems. When they manage their housing, they want the interaction to feel effortless and casual -- like texting a friend, not like using enterprise software. Ease is what converts 'I have to check the platform' into 'I will just check the platform.' The emotional distance between obligation and choice is the definition of ease.

do: Use first names: 'Sent to Nneka' not 'Sent to your host'
Use contractions and short sentences: 'Got it. She usually responds in a day.'
Mirror the language a friend would use: 'Swap Thu for Tue?' not 'Replace scheduled date with alternative date'
Confirm actions with conversational acknowledgments: 'Done' or 'Sent' rather than 'Your request has been successfully submitted'
dont: Use formal request language: 'Submit Date Change Request' sounds like filing a form, not managing your week
Use platform jargon: 'Initiate modification' or 'Process rescheduling' are internal terms that create emotional distance
Add unnecessary confirmations: 'Are you sure you want to proceed?' for a simple date swap creates anxiety where none should exist
Use passive voice: 'Your request has been submitted' distances the guest from their action. 'Sent to Nneka' connects them to the human on the other end.
copy_guidelines.example_good: Swap Oct 15 for Oct 22? Same rate. [Send to Nneka]
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Date Change Request: Replace October 15, 2025 with October 22, 2025. Rate adjustment: $0.00. [Submit Request]

animation_feel.feel_description: A message-send bounce. When the guest confirms a date change or action, the confirmation animates with a slight spring overshoot -- the same physics a chat bubble uses when it appears in a messaging app. The sensation is 'message sent' not 'form submitted.' The spring easing creates a playful, lightweight feeling that contrasts with the rigid, weightless feel of traditional form submissions. On the receiving end, when the host responds, the response appears with the same spring -- creating a conversational rhythm that feels like a text thread.
animation_feel.duration_range: 200-250ms for the send animation with spring overshoot

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest needs to change a date and is deciding whether to text the host or use the platform.
tension_relief.relief_point: The platform flow is faster, easier, and more informative than a text message. The guest sees available dates (no guessing), sees the cost (no surprises), and completes the change in three taps (faster than composing a text).
tension_relief.timing: The relief window is narrow: the guest must reach the date change flow and see its simplicity within 10 seconds of deciding to make a change. If the flow takes longer to initiate than opening the text app, the guest will choose texting.

personalization_signals: Use the host's first name in all confirmations and status updates
Reference specific dates and nights, not abstract time ranges
If the guest has a pattern (always swaps Thursdays), preemptively suggest: 'Swap this Thursday too?'
Show the host's response pattern: 'Nneka usually responds in a few hours' to set casual expectations

anti_patterns.pattern: Using formal, bureaucratic language for routine active-lease interactions
anti_patterns.reason: Formal language creates emotional distance between the guest and the platform. The guest is managing their weekly living arrangement, not filing a legal claim. Bureaucratic copy ('Your Date Change Request has been submitted for review') makes the platform feel like an institution the guest must comply with rather than a tool that serves them.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Date Modification Request #4827 has been submitted. The host will be notified. Please allow 48 hours for processing.

elements.title: The Administrative Guilt Accumulator: Transforming Obligation Into Reflection
elements.problem: The Stays Manager activates a 'Review' button after every completed stay. Over 13 weeks, unreviewed stays accumulate as a visible to-do list on the page the guest visits weekly. Each unreviewed stay is a small guilt signal: the platform is silently asking 'Why have you not reviewed Week 3 yet?' while the guest is just trying to check their current week status. Kahneman's ego depletion research shows that the guilt from unfinished tasks draws from the same System 2 pool as the tasks themselves -- meaning the guilt is cognitively depleting even when the guest does not act on it. The emotional trajectory is: Week 1-3, the guest dutifully reviews each stay. Week 4-6, reviews become perfunctory (5 stars, no text). Week 7+, the guest stops reviewing but sees the accumulating 'Review' buttons on every visit, creating a background hum of guilt that makes the Stays Manager feel like a nagging parent rather than a helpful dashboard. By Week 13, the guest's emotional association with the Stays Manager is 'the page that makes me feel behind' rather than 'the page that helps me manage my stay.' This emotional contamination damages the guest's entire relationship with the platform.
elements.solution: Eliminate the guilt accumulator by replacing per-stay review buttons with three batched review moments at natural reflection points (Week 4, midpoint, final). Between review moments, the Stays Manager shows no review prompts at all. Completed stays display 'Reviewed' or remain quietly unmarked -- never an active 'Review' button that the guest must consciously choose to ignore. When a batched review moment arrives, it appears as a warm invitation, not an obligation: 'You have been here 4 weeks. How is it going?' rather than 'Rate your stay for Week 1, Week 2, Week 3, and Week 4.' The emotional reframe is: reviewing is a moment of reflection offered at the right time, not an ongoing obligation imposed by the platform's data structure. The guest should feel 'Oh, time to reflect on how this is going' (pleasant) not 'Oh, I still have not reviewed five stays' (guilt).

evidence.quote: An effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around.
evidence.insight: The guilt of unreviewed stays is itself a form of ego depletion. Each time the guest sees a 'Review' button and decides not to act, they exert self-control (resisting the guilt). This depletion accumulates over weeks, making the Stays Manager feel increasingly burdensome even when the guest is not reviewing.

evidence.quote: Hybrid workers... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week.
evidence.insight: The target guest is a busy professional. Administrative guilt from a housing platform competes with professional obligations for the same depleted cognitive resources. A platform that makes the guest feel 'behind' on reviews while they are already behind on work emails creates an emotional association that discourages return visits.

elements.emotion_rationale: Lightness is the absence of unnecessary weight. The Stays Manager should feel like a surface the guest bounces off of quickly -- check status, see nothing needs attention, leave. Accumulated review obligations add weight that slows each visit and darkens the emotional tone. Lightness is achieved by removing the weight: no visible obligations, no guilt signals, no accumulating to-do list. The guest feels light when the platform asks nothing of them on most visits and offers a natural reflection moment on a few.

do: Frame reviews as reflection: 'You have been here 4 weeks. How is it going?' invites thought rather than demanding compliance
Acknowledge that reviews are optional in the framing: 'If you have a moment' or 'When you are ready'
Pre-fill context so the guest does not have to recall specifics: 'Your stays covered Oct 1-25 at [property]'
After submission, thank briefly and naturally: 'Thanks. Your feedback helps [host name] improve.'
dont: Show accumulating 'Review' buttons on completed stays -- this is the single biggest emotional anti-pattern in the Stays Manager
Use obligation language: 'You have 5 unreviewed stays' or 'Please review your recent stays'
Send reminder emails or notifications about pending reviews -- this extends the guilt off-platform
Make the review a blocking condition for anything: 'Complete your review to access [feature]'
copy_guidelines.example_good: You have been at [property] for 4 weeks now. Got a minute to share how it is going?
copy_guidelines.example_bad: You have 4 unreviewed stays. Please rate your experience for: Week 1, Week 2, Week 3, Week 4.

animation_feel.feel_description: A gentle arrival. The batched review card slides down into the hero position from above with a slow, gravity-like ease -- it descends into view like a note being placed on a table, not like a notification demanding attention. If dismissed, the card slides back up and out with a lighter, faster motion, communicating 'no pressure, it is gone.' The sensation is an invitation that respects a declined response.
animation_feel.duration_range: 250ms entrance, 200ms dismissal (faster out than in, respecting the 'no thanks' decision)

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest sees accumulating unreviewed stays and feels guilty about not completing them, or feels burdened by the platform's persistent ask.
tension_relief.relief_point: With batched reviews, the Stays Manager shows no review obligations on 10 out of 13 weekly visits. The three review moments are framed as invitations, not demands. Dismissing a review prompt has no visible consequence -- no accumulating badge, no guilt signal.
tension_relief.timing: The relief is structural, not momentary: the guest feels lighter on every visit because the page never shows a to-do list. The three review moments each last one visit (if dismissed, they move to secondary position for 2 more visits, then disappear entirely).

personalization_signals: Review prompt references the specific weeks and dates covered, not generic 'your stays'
If the guest submitted a previous batched review, the midpoint review acknowledges it: 'You shared your thoughts at Week 4. How have things been since?'
If the guest's prior review was negative, the review prompt gently checks in: 'You flagged some concerns at Week 4. Have things improved?'
Final review uses a warm lease-end framing: 'Your time at [property] is wrapping up. Looking back, how was it?'

anti_patterns.pattern: Displaying a 'Review' button on every completed stay row in the Stays Table
anti_patterns.reason: Accumulating review buttons create a guilt accumulator that worsens on every visit. By Week 8, the guest sees 5+ unreviewed stays, which makes the Stays Manager feel like a list of failures rather than a helpful dashboard. The emotional contamination from this pattern poisons the guest's entire experience of the page they visit most often.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Week 1: [Review] | Week 2: [Review] | Week 3: [Review] | Week 4: [Review] | Week 5: [Review] -- all visible simultaneously in the stays table.

elements.title: The Discovery Promise: Setting Honest Expectations That Survive Contact With Reality
elements.problem: Kahneman's priming and associative coherence research demonstrates that the first encounter with a brand activates an associative network that shapes interpretation of every subsequent interaction. If the guest's first encounter with Split Lease primes 'flexible, easy housing,' then every friction point -- rescheduling complexity, pricing confusion, availability constraints -- contradicts the primed network and triggers cognitive dissonance. The Nneka call reveals exactly this disconnect: the platform promises flexibility, but Brad's actual experience of rescheduling involves texting the host, waiting for manual availability checks, and discovering that dates cost more than expected. The emotional damage is not caused by the friction itself -- every platform has friction. It is caused by the gap between what was promised at discovery and what is delivered during the lease. This is Kahneman's violation model: 'System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.' The discovery touchpoint builds the model. The active lease tests it.
elements.solution: Design discovery messaging that honestly prepares the guest for the reality of mid-term housing negotiation. Instead of promising 'easy flexibility,' promise 'transparent flexibility': 'Find mid-term housing with clear pricing, real-time availability, and a rescheduling tool that shows you exactly what changes cost before you commit.' This sets an expectation that is specific enough to be tested and honest enough to survive contact with reality. The emotional principle is: under-promise on ease, over-deliver on transparency. The guest who expects 'transparent flexibility' and encounters a rate comparison display feels the platform delivered on its promise. The guest who expects 'easy flexibility' and encounters any friction at all feels deceived. At search and listing evaluation, continue the honesty: show schedule compatibility upfront (not after the guest invests evaluation effort), show rate ranges when dates span seasons (not single misleading rates), and show 'proposal-based booking' clearly (not 'book now' language that implies instant booking). Every discovery touchpoint should set an expectation that the Stays Manager can fulfill 13 weeks later.

evidence.quote: Ideas that have been evoked trigger many other ideas, in a spreading cascade of activity in your brain... yielding a self-reinforcing pattern of cognitive, emotional, and physical responses that is both diverse and integrated -- it has been called associatively coherent.
evidence.insight: Whatever the guest encounters at discovery primes an entire associative network. If 'Split Lease' is first associated with 'instant' and 'easy,' every subsequent friction (proposal waiting, rescheduling negotiation) contradicts the primed network. If the first association is 'transparent' and 'fair,' friction is expected and tolerable.

evidence.quote: Brad and I had our contract ended in January or February... it's not working financially... the new dates are priced higher now.
evidence.insight: Brad's experience reveals that mid-term housing inherently involves rescheduling and pricing variability. Discovery messaging that hides this reality sets up the guest for disappointment. Discovery messaging that frames it as a managed, transparent feature sets the guest up for realistic expectations that the platform can meet.

elements.emotion_rationale: Trust at discovery is the foundation for every subsequent emotional interaction. A guest who trusts the platform's honesty at discovery will interpret mid-lease friction as 'the platform warned me about this.' A guest who feels misled at discovery will interpret the same friction as 'they lied to me.' Trust is not built by promising a perfect experience -- it is built by accurately describing the real one. The guest who was told 'flexibility with transparency' and encounters transparent pricing controls feels trust confirmed. The guest who was told 'easy, flexible housing' and encounters any complexity feels trust violated.

do: Name the reality: 'Mid-term housing with proposal-based booking' not 'Book your perfect space now'
Describe the actual flow: 'Find a space, submit a proposal, negotiate terms, move in' not 'Find and book instantly'
Lead with the differentiator: 'See what rescheduling costs before you commit' is specific and testable
Use language at discovery that the Stays Manager will echo: if discovery says 'transparent pricing,' the Stays Manager should show rate comparisons
dont: Promise ease when the actual flow involves negotiation: 'Easy, flexible housing' sets an expectation that any friction violates
Use Airbnb-style instant-booking language when the model is proposal-based: 'Book now' on a proposal flow is a lie of omission
Hide the negotiation aspect: the proposal-counter-accept flow is the core product, not a bug. Present it as a feature.
Promise flexibility without qualification: 'Flexibility' means different things to different people. Specify: 'Reschedule dates with real-time availability and upfront pricing'
copy_guidelines.example_good: Mid-term housing that adapts to your schedule. See available dates, know the cost of changes, and manage your stay in one place.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Find flexible housing in seconds. Book your perfect space and move in hassle-free.

animation_feel.feel_description: A grounded entry. Discovery page elements load with a subtle upward movement (8px translate) and fade-in, creating a sense of solidity and substance. Nothing bounces, springs, or overshoots -- the landing page feels planted and confident, like a handshake rather than a wave. The sensation is 'this is a real product, not a marketing illusion.'
animation_feel.duration_range: 300-400ms for initial page element entrances, staggered by 50ms per element

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest is evaluating whether Split Lease is legitimate and whether its promises will hold up during an actual lease.
tension_relief.relief_point: Discovery copy names the actual process (proposals, negotiation, rescheduling with pricing) rather than hiding it behind marketing abstraction. The guest thinks 'they are telling me how it really works, not just how they want me to think it works.'
tension_relief.timing: Trust must form in the first 10 seconds of the discovery page. If the guest's System 1 labels the platform as 'too good to be true' or 'another Airbnb clone,' that impression is extremely difficult to reverse. Honest, specific language in the first 10 seconds prevents these labels from forming.

personalization_signals: If the guest arrived via a specific search query (e.g., 'midterm housing NYC weeknights'), echo that context on the landing page
Show real listing examples relevant to the guest's apparent need, not generic showcase properties
If referral data is available, reference it: 'Your friend [name] uses Split Lease for weeknight stays in [city]'
Surface the guest persona explicitly: 'Designed for hybrid workers who need a place during the work week'

anti_patterns.pattern: Discovery messaging that promises ease and simplicity when the actual product involves negotiation and pricing variability
anti_patterns.reason: Every unfulfilled promise at discovery becomes a trust violation during the lease. Kahneman's associative coherence means the discovery promise primes the guest's expectations for the entire journey. A guest primed for 'easy' interprets normal platform friction as failure. A guest primed for 'transparent' interprets the same friction as the system working as described.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Split Lease: Find and book flexible housing in minutes. No hassle, no surprises.

elements.title: The Invisible System: When the Platform Disappears, the Guest Feels Free
elements.problem: The ideal Stays Manager visit takes under 5 seconds: glance at the hero card, confirm everything is on track, leave. But the current design forces the guest into a longer engagement cycle: scan the table, find the current week, parse the status, check for pending changes, check the payment schedule. Each element demands attention even when nothing requires action. Kahneman describes System 2's 'natural speed' as 'a comfortable walk' with 'little strain' and contrasts it with the forced acceleration of demanding tasks. The weekly Stays Manager check should be a stroll, but the current information density forces a jog. Over 13 weeks, the accumulated effort transforms the check-in from a neutral habit into a mildly dreaded obligation. The guest does not dread any specific content -- they dread the effort of processing a full page when they only needed one data point. The emotional goal is invisibility: the platform should become so effortlessly readable that the guest stops noticing it. When the platform disappears from conscious awareness, the guest feels free -- free to focus on their work, their week, their life. When the platform demands conscious parsing, the guest feels managed.
elements.solution: Design the default Stays Manager view for the 90% case: nothing needs the guest's attention. The hero card shows the current week status. Below it, a single line: 'All payments current. No pending changes.' If both statements are true, the guest has their answer in one card and one line. The full details (stays table, payment schedule, date changes) exist behind expand controls for the 10% of visits where something actually needs attention. The emotional principle is: the platform earns the guest's trust by being quiet when there is nothing to say. Silence is not absence -- it is confidence. A dashboard that screams 'everything is fine, look at all the things that are fine!' is not reassuring; it is exhausting. A dashboard that says 'Week 7. All clear.' and then gets out of the way communicates competence. The emotional reward for the guest is the feeling of freedom: 'I checked, everything is fine, I have my morning back.'

evidence.quote: System 2 also has a natural speed. You expend some mental energy in random thoughts and in monitoring what goes on around you even when your mind does nothing in particular, but there is little strain... Just like a stroll.
evidence.insight: The weekly check-in should operate at System 2's natural speed -- a stroll, not a sprint. The platform achieves this by presenting only the minimum information needed to confirm the status quo, and hiding everything else behind deliberate access. The guest walks through the page without breaking stride.

evidence.quote: Hybrid workers... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week.
evidence.insight: The hybrid worker's Monday morning is not 'Stays Manager time' -- it is 'get to work time.' The platform must occupy the smallest possible slice of the guest's attention and then release them. Every second the platform holds the guest's attention beyond what is necessary is a second stolen from their real priorities.

elements.emotion_rationale: Freedom is the feeling that the platform serves the guest rather than demanding from them. The guest chose Split Lease to simplify their housing, not to acquire a weekly management task. When the platform delivers its value invisibly -- accurate stays, processed payments, no surprises -- the guest feels free. When the platform demands parsing, scanning, and decision-making on routine visits, the guest feels captured. Freedom is the emotional state that drives the highest satisfaction and the strongest referral behavior: 'You do not even have to think about it.'

do: Use the shortest possible confirmation: 'All clear' or 'On track' rather than 'All of your scheduled stays and payments are currently in good standing'
Let the absence of information communicate health: if there are no pending changes, do not show the Date Change section at all on the default view
Use data, not description: 'Week 7. Oct 14-18. In Progress.' is three data points with zero filler words
Reserve words for exceptions: when something needs attention, use more words to explain. When nothing needs attention, use fewer.
dont: Fill silence with reassurance: 'Everything looks great! All your stays are on track!' is emotional padding that creates noise without value
Show information that requires no action: payment rows that are all 'Paid' do not need to be visible on every visit
Add motivational copy: 'You are doing great as a guest!' or 'Keep up the good work!' is patronizing in a housing management tool
Expand sections by default that are normally empty: the Date Change section should be collapsed when there are no pending changes
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Welcome back! Here is your weekly update. Your current stay for Week 7 is in progress. You are staying at [property name] from October 14 to October 18. All payments are up to date and there are no pending date change requests. Have a great week!

animation_feel.feel_description: Stillness. On routine visits where everything is on track, the page loads with minimal animation -- just the hero card fading in over 150ms. No staggered entrances, no sliding panels, no attention-grabbing transitions. The sensation is opening a book to a familiar page. The page is simply there, instantly readable, instantly dismissible. Animation is reserved for the rare occasions when something has changed -- a new status, a pending action, a payment processed. On those occasions, the animation serves as a contrast signal: 'this is different from the usual stillness.'
animation_feel.duration_range: 150ms for routine page load; 200-300ms for exception-state animations when something has changed

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest opens the Stays Manager wondering 'Do I need to deal with anything today?'
tension_relief.relief_point: The hero card and summary line answer 'No, everything is fine' in a single glance. The guest closes the page within 5 seconds.
tension_relief.timing: Relief must arrive within 2 seconds of page load. The hero card must be above the fold and fully rendered before the guest's eyes finish their first scan of the page.

personalization_signals: The hero card shows the guest's week number, creating a personal timeline ('Week 7 of 13' is uniquely theirs)
The summary line adapts to what is actually relevant: if the guest has never used date changes, the Date Change section does not appear at all
On the guest's final few weeks, a gentle closing note appears: '2 weeks remaining' -- personal, temporal, not generic
The page remembers the guest's preference: if they always expand the payment schedule, it loads expanded; if they never do, it stays collapsed

anti_patterns.pattern: Showing all sections expanded by default on every visit, even when nothing requires attention
anti_patterns.reason: An expanded dashboard full of green checkmarks and 'Paid' statuses is not reassuring -- it is overwhelming. The guest must parse every section to confirm that nothing needs attention, which is cognitively expensive. A collapsed default view with a single summary line ('All clear') is both faster to process and more emotionally reassuring because it communicates 'we checked, you do not need to.'
anti_patterns.example_bad: The Stays Manager loads with the full 13-row stays table, the 4-row payment schedule, and the date change history all expanded and visible, requiring the guest to scroll through 3 screens of content to confirm nothing needs their attention.
